utterance: WANT to be a school-master, do you? You? Well, what would you do in Flat Crick deestrick, I'd like to know? Why, the boys have driv off the last two, and licked the one afore them like blazes. You might teach a summer school, when nothin' but children come. But I 'low it takes a right smart man to be school-master in Flat Crick in the winter. They'd pitch you out of doors, sonny, neck and heels, afore Christmas.
speaker: Old Jack Means

utterance: you, Bull! git aout,' you pup!
speaker: Old Jack Means

utterance: you see, we a'n't none of your saft sort in these diggin's. It takes a man to boss this deestrick. Howsumdever, ef you think you kin trust your hide in Flat Crick school-house I ha'n't got no 'bjection. But ef you git licked, don't come on us. Flat Crick don't pay no 'nsur ance, you bet! Any other trustees? Wal, yes. But as I pay the most taxes, t'others jist let me run the thing. You can begin right off a Monday. They a'n't been no other applications. You see, it takes grit to apply for this school. The last master had a black eye for a month. But, as I wuz sayin', you can jist roll up and wade in. I 'low you've got spunk, maybe, and that goes for a heap sight more'n sinnoo with boys. Walk in, and stay over Sunday with me. You'll hev' to board roun', and I guess you better begin here.
speaker: Old Jack Means

utterance: Ef Bull once takes a holt, heaven and yarth can't make him let go.
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: Bill, ax the master ef he'd like to hunt coons. I'd like to take the starch out uv the stuck-up feller.
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: I 'Nough said.
speaker: Bill Means

utterance: You durn't do it.
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: I don't take no sech a dare.
speaker: Bill Means

utterance: I say, mister, mister, they's a coo what's been a eatin' our chickens lately, and we'rc goin' to try to ketch 'the varmint. You wouldn't like to take a coon hunt nor nothin', would you?
speaker: Bill Means

utterance: Why, yes, there's nothing I should like better, if I could only be sure Bull wouldn't mistake me for the coon.
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: Ef Bull once takes a holt, heaven and yarth' can't make him let go.
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: Purty peart kind of a master. Guess you better be a little easy on him. Hey?
speaker: Old Jack Means

utterance: I'll be dog-on'd, ef I hadn't 'ruther hear the master tell them whoppin yarns than to go to a circus the best day I ever seed!
speaker: Bill Means

utterance: I guess you're a little skeered by what the old man said, a'n't you?
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: What will you do with the tough boys? You a'n't no match for 'em.
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: I don't know.
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: What would you do with me, for instance ?
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: I sha'n't have any trouble with you.
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: Why, I'm the wust chap of all. I thrashed the last master, myself.
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: You won't thrash me, though.
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: Pshaw! I 'low I could whip you in an inch of your life with my left hand, and never half try.
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: I know that as well as you do.
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: Well, a'n't you afraid of me, then?
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: Not a bit.
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: Why a'n't you afraid of me?
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: Because you and I are going to be friends.
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: And what about t'others?
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: I am not afraid of all the other boys put together.
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: You a'n't! The mischief! How's that?
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: Well, I'm not afraid of them because you and I are going to be friends, and you can whip all of them together. You'll do the fighting and I'll do the teaching.
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: Bow-wow! wow-wow!
speaker: Puppy

utterance: I am sorry, that any scholar in this school could be so mean as to shut up his brother in such a place as that!
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: William Means, will you be so good as to put ths do out of doors?
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: the master wouldn't be much in a tussle, but he had a heap of thunder and lightning in him.
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: Don't believe he'll do. Don't thrash enough. Boys won't l'arn 'less you thrash 'em, says I. Leastways, mine won't. Lay it on good is what I says to a master. Lay it on good. Don't do no harm. Lickin' and l'arnin' goes together. No lickin', no l'arnin', says I. Lickin' and l'arnin,' lickin' and larnin', is the good ole way.
speaker: Mr. Pete Jones

utterance: You see,
speaker: Mrs. Old Jack Means

utterance: Mr. Hartsook, my ole man's purty well along in the world. He's got a ight smart lot of this world's plunder,' one way and another.
speaker: Mrs. Old Jack Means

utterance: You see, we moved in here nigh upon twenty-five years ago. 'Twas when my Jack, him as died afore Bud was born, was a baby. Bud'll be twenty-one the fif' of next June.
speaker: Mrs. Old Jack Means

utterance: Jack,' says I, ‘Jack, do you git a plenty while you're a-gittin'. Git a plenty while you're a-gittin',' says I, 'fer 'twon't never be no cheaper'n 'tis now,' and it ha'n't been; I knowed 'twouldn't,
speaker: Mrs. Old Jack Means

utterance: Git a plenty while you're a-gittin',' says I. I could see, you know, they was a powerful sight of money in Congress land. That's what made me say, 'Git a plenty while you're a-gittin'.
speaker: Mrs. Old Jack Means

utterance: You see as how, Mr. Hartsook, the man what gits my Mirandy'll do well. Flat Crick land's wuth nigh upon a hundred a' acre.
speaker: Mrs. Old Jack Means

utterance: Well, Shocky, what is it?
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: Why, Mr. Hartsook, they's a pond down under the school-house,'
speaker: Shocky

utterance: Yes, Shocky, I know that. What about it? The trustees haven't come to fill it up, have they?
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: Oh! no, sir; but Hank Banta, you know- '
speaker: Shocky

utterance: Has Henry fallen in and got a ducking, Shocky?
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: Oh! no, sir; he wants to git you in, you see.
speaker: Shocky

utterance: Well, I won't go in, though, Shocky.
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: But, you see, he's been and gone and pulled back the board that you have to step on to git ahind your desk; he's been and gone and pulled back the board so as you can't help a-tippin' it up, and a-sowsin' right in ef you step there.
speaker: Shocky

utterance: And so you came to tell me.
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: How he looked at me! how he did. look!
speaker: Shocky

utterance: What a quare boy Shocky is!
speaker: Betsey Short

utterance: He just likes to wander round alone. I see him a-comin' out of the sugar camp just now. He's been in there half an hour.
speaker: Betsey Short

utterance: Just step round behind me, Henry, and you can see how I do this,
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: Why, Henry!
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: How did this happen?'
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: Thunder and lightning! what a manager you air, Mr. Hartsook!
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: I 'LOW,
speaker: Mrs. Old Jack Means

utterance: I 'low they'll app'int the Squire to gin out the words to-night. They mos' always do, you see, kase he's the peartest' ole man in this deestrick; and I 'low some of the young fellers would have to git up and dust ef they would keep up to him. And he uses sech remarkable smart words. He speaks so polite, too. But laws! don't I remember when he was poarer nor Job's turkey? Twenty year ago, when he come to these 'ere diggin's, that air Squire Hawkins was a poar Yankee school-master, that said 'pail' instid of bucket, and that called a cow a 'caow,' and that couldn't tell to save his gizzard what we meant by 'low' and by right smart. But he's larnt our ways now, an' he's jest as civilized as the rest of us. You would-n know he'd ever been a Yankee. He didn't stay poar long. Not he. He jest married a right rich girl! He! he!
speaker: Mrs. Old Jack Means

utterance: He didn't stay poar, you bet a hoss!
speaker: Mrs. Old Jack Means

utterance: He married rich, you see,
speaker: Mrs. Old Jack Means

utterance: His wife hadn't no book-larnin'. She'd been through the spellin'book wunst, and had got as fur as 'asperity' on it a second time. But she couldn't read a word when she was married, and never could. She warn't overly smart. She hadn't hardly got the sense the law allows. But schools was skase in them air days, and, besides, book-larnin' don't do no good to a woman. Makes her stuck up. I never knowed but one gal in my life as had ciphered into fractions, and she was so dog-on stuck up that she turned up her nose one night at a apple-peelin' bekase I tuck a sheet off the bed to splice out the table-cloth, which was 73 ruther short. And the sheet was mos' clean too. Had-n been slep on more'n wunst or twicet. But I was goin' fer to say that when Squire Hawkins married Virginny Gray he got a heap o' money, or, what's the same thing mostly, a heap o' good land. And that's better'n book-larnin', says I. Ef a gal had gone clean through all eddication, and got to the rule of three itself, that would-n buy a feather. bed. Squire Hawkins jest put eddication agin the gal's farm, and traded even, an' ef ary one of 'em got swindled, I never heerd no complaints.
speaker: Mrs. Old Jack Means

utterance: I say, ole woman,
speaker: Old Jack Means

utterance: I say, wot is all this 'ere spoutin' about the Square fer?
speaker: Old Jack Means

utterance: Hanner, you kin come along, too, ef you're a mind, when you git the dishes washed,
speaker: Mrs. Old Jack Means

utterance: That' gal don't never show no gratitude fer favors;
speaker: Mrs. Old Jack Means

utterance: We must take care of one another, boys. Who will vol. unteer to take turns sitting up with Henry?
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: William Means and myself will sit up to-night,
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: I 'low,
speaker: Old Jack Means

utterance: I 'low our friend the Square is jest the man to boss this 'ere consarn to-night. Ef nobody objects, I'll app'int him. Come, Square, don't be bashful. Walk up to the trough, fodder or no fodder, as the man said to his donkey.
speaker: Old Jack Means

utterance: Ladies and gentlemen,
speaker: Squire Hawkins

utterance: young men and maidens, raley I'm obleeged to Mr. Means fer this honor,
speaker: Squire Hawkins

utterance: I feel in the inmost compartments of my animal spirits a most happifying sense of the success and futility of all my endeavors to sarve the people of Flat Creek deestrick, and the people of Tomkins township, in my weak way and manner.
speaker: Squire Hawkins

utterance: I feel as if I could be grandiloquent on this in teresting occasion,
speaker: Squire Hawkins

utterance: but raley I must forego any such exertions. It is spelling you want. Spelling is the corner-stone, the grand, underlying subterfuge, of a good eddication. I put the spellin'-book prepared by the great Daniel Webster alongside the Bible. I do, raley. I think I may put it ahead of the Bible. For if it wurn't fer spellin'-books and sich occasions as these, where would the Bible be? I should like to know. man who got up, who compounded this work of inextricable valoo was a benufactor to the whole human race or any other.
speaker: Squire Hawkins

utterance: I app'int Larkin Lanham and Jeems Buchanan fer captings,
speaker: Squire Hawkins

utterance: I take the master,
speaker: Larkin Lanham

utterance: And I take Jeems Phillips.
speaker: Jeems Buchanan

utterance: Theodolite.
speaker: the Squire

utterance: T-h-e, the, o-d, od, theod, o, theodo, l-y-t-e, theodolite.
speaker: Jim Phillips

utterance: Next.
speaker: the Squire

utterance:
Gewhilliky crickets! Thunder and lightning!
Licked him all to smash!
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: That beats my time all hol ler!
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: He's powerful smart, is the master. He'll beat the whole kit and tuck of 'em afore he's through. I know'd he was smart.
speaker: Old Jack Means

utterance: That's the reason I tuck him.
speaker: Mr. Means

utterance: Yaas, but he don't lick enough. Not nigh. No lickin', no larnin', says I.
speaker: Pete Jones

utterance: D-a-u, dau-
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: Next.
speaker: the Squire

utterance: Hanner beat! my Hanner spelled down the master!
speaker: Shocky

utterance: As our friend Hanner Thomson is the only one left on her side, she will have to spell against nearly all on t'other side. I shall therefore take the liberty of procrastinating the completion of this interesting and exacting contest until to-morrow evening. I hope our friend Hanner may again carry off the cypress crown of glory. There is nothing better for us than healthful and kindly simulation.
speaker: the Squire

utterance: Tell me your circumstances. I am sure I can help you in something.
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: No, no! you cannot. No one can help me. Only time and God. I must go, Mr. Hartsook.
speaker: Hannah Thomson

utterance: You're a purty gal, a'n't you? You're a purty gal, a'n't you? You air! Yes, you air!!
speaker: Mrs. Means

utterance: A purty gal! you! Yes! you air a mighty purty gal!
speaker: Mrs. Means

utterance:
To be a-santerin' along the big road after ten o'clock with the master! Who knows whether he's a fit man fer anybody to go with? Arter all I've been and gone and done fer you! That's the way you pay me! Disgrace me! Yes, I say disgrace me!
You're a mean, deceitful thing. Stuck up bekase you spelt the master down. Ketch me lettin' you got to spellin'-school to-morry night! Ketch ME!
Yes, ketch ME, I say!
speaker: Mrs. Means

utterance: Looky here, marm, it seems to me you're a-makin' a blamed furss about nothin'. Don't yell so's they'll hear you three or four mile. You'll have everybody 'tween here and Clifty waked up.
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: That's the way I'm treated. That's the vay I'm treated. You allers take sides with that air hussy agin your own flesh and blood. You don't keer how much trouble I have. Not you. Not a dog-on'd bit. I may be disgraced by that air ongrateful critter, and you set right here in my own house and sass me about it. A purty fellow you air! An' me a-delvin' and a-drudgin' fer you all my born days. A purty son, a'n't you?
speaker: Mrs. Means

utterance: Come in, stranger, come in. You'll find this 'ere house full of brats, but I guess you kin kick your way around among 'em. Take a cheer. Here, git out! go to thunder with you!
speaker: Mr. Pete Jones

utterance: I believe in trainin' up children to mind when they're spoke to.
speaker: Mr. Pete Jones

utterance: P'raps you'd like a bed. Well, jest climb up the ladder on the outside of the house. Takes up a thunderin' sight of room to have a stairs inside, and we ha'n't got no room to spare. You'll find a bed in the furdest corner. My Pete's already got half of it, and you can take t'other half. Ef Pate goes to takin' his half in the middle, and tryin' to make you take yourn on both sides, jest kick him.
speaker: Mr. Pete Jones

utterance: Don't want no saft-handed help!
speaker: Mr. Pete Jones

utterance: Hanner's got a bad cold this mornin' from bein' out last night, and she can't come to spellin'-school to-night.
speaker: Mirandy Means

utterance: Hannah was a smart girl.
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: Yes, Bud thinks so.
speaker: Mirandy Means

utterance: Does he?
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: I should say so. What's him and her been a-courtin' fer for a year ef he didn't think she was smart? Marm don't like it; but ef Bud and her does, and they seem to, I don't see as it's marm's lookout.
speaker: Mirandy Means

utterance: Did you hear the news? The Dutchman's house was robbed last night.
speaker: Shocky

utterance: I s'pose that them air fellers what robbed your house must a come down from Jinkins Run. They're the blamedest set up there I ever see.
speaker: Mr. Pete Jones

utterance: Ya-as, put how did Yinkins vellers know dat I sell te medder to te Shquire, hey? How tid Yinkins know anyting 'bout the Shquire's bayin' me dree huntert in te hard gashhey?
speaker: Peter Schroeder

utterance: Some scoundrels down in these 'ere parts is a-layin' in with Jinkins Run, I'll bet a hoss.
speaker: Mr. Pete Jones

utterance: Now, ef I could find the feller that's a-helpin' them scoundrels rob us folks, I'd help stretch him to the neardest tree.
speaker: Mr. Pete Jones

utterance: So vood I. I'd shtretch him dill he baid me my dree huntert tollars pack, so I vood.
speaker: Peter Schroeder

utterance: PAP wants to know ef you would spend to morry and Sunday at our house?
speaker: one of Squire Hawkins's girls

utterance: Poor old tree!
speaker: Shocky

utterance: Why do you say 'poor old tree'?
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: 'Cause it's lonesome. All its old friends is dead and chopped down, and there's their stumps a-standin' jes like grave-stones. It must be lonesome. Some folks says it don't feel, but I think it does. Everything seems to think and feel. See it nodding its head to them other trees in the woods, and a-wantin' to shake hands! But it can't move. I think that tree must a growed in the night.
speaker: Shocky

utterance: Why, Shocky?
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: 'Cause it's so crooked, must a growed when they was no light so as it could see how to grow.
speaker: Shocky

utterance: I guess that tree feels just like me. Don't you?
speaker: Shocky

utterance: Why, how do you feel?
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: Kind o' bad and lonesome, and like as if I wanted to die, you know. Felt that way ever sence they put my father into the graveyard, and sent my mother to the poor-house and Hanner to ole Miss Means's. What kind of a place is a poorhouse? Is it a poorer place than Means's? I wish I was dead and one of them clouds was a-carryin' me and Hanner and mother up to where father's gone, you know! I wonder if God forgets all about poor folks when their father dies and their mother gits into the poor-house? Do you think He does? Seems so to me. Maybe God lost track of my father when he come away from England and crossed over the sea. Don't nobody on Flat Creek keer fer God, and I guess God don't keer fer Flat Creek. But I would, though, ef he'd git my mother out of the poor-house and git Hanner away from Means's, and let me kiss my mother every night, you know, and sleep on my Hanner's arm, jes like I used to afore father died, you see.
speaker: Shocky

utterance: It was real good in Mr. Pearson to take me, wasn't it? Else I'd a been 117 bound out tell I was twenty-one, maybe, to some mean man like Ole Means. And I a'n't but seven. And it would take me fourteen years to git twenty. one, and I never could live with my mother again after Hanner gets done her time. 'Cause, you see, Hanner'll be through in three more year, and I'll be ten and able to work, and we'll git a little place about as big as Granny Sanders's, and
speaker: Shocky

utterance: Why, doctor, howdy, howdy! Come in, take a cheer. I am glad to see you. I 'lowed you'd come. Old Dr. Flounder used to say he larnt lots o' things of me. But most of the doctors sence hez been kinder stuck up, you know. But I know'd you fer a man of intelligence.
speaker: Granny Sanders

utterance: Many's the case I've cured with yarbs and things. Nigh upon twenty year ago they was a man lived over on Wild Cat Run as had a breakin'. out on his side. 'Twas the left side, jes below the waist. Doctor couldn't do nothin'. 'Twas Doctor Peacham. He never would have nothin' to do with 'ole woman's cures.' Well, the man was goin' to die. Everybody seed that. And they come a-drivin' away over here all the way from the Wild Cat. Think of that air! I never was so flustered. Opper MRS. MRANS N 矍 ​ 121 says, But as soon as I laid eyes on that air man, I says I, that air man, says I, has got the shingles, says I. I know'd the minute I seed it. And if they'd gone clean around, nothing could a saved him. I says, says I, git me a black cat. So I jist killed a black cat, and let the blood run all over the swellin'. I tell you, doctor, they's nothin' like it. That man was well in a month.
speaker: Granny Sanders

utterance: Did you use the blood warm?
speaker: Dr. Small

utterance: Laws, yes; I jest let it run right out of the cat's tail onto the breakin'-out. And fer airesipelus, I don't know nothin' so good as the blood of a black hen.
speaker: Granny Sanders

utterance: How old?
speaker: Dr. Small

utterance: There you showed yer science, doctor! They's no power in a pullet. The older the black hen the better. And you know the cure fer rheumatiz?
speaker: Granny Sanders

utterance: That's ile from a black dog. Ef it's ren dered right, it'll knock the hind sights off of any rheumatiz you ever see. But it must be rendered in the dark of the moon. Else a black dog's ile a'n't worth no more nor a white one's.
speaker: Granny Sanders

utterance: I 'low somebody not fur away is in this 'ere business!
speaker: Granny Sanders

utterance: Who d'ye s'pose 'tis ?
speaker: Granny Sanders

utterance: I dunno anybody that's been 'bout here long as could be suspected.
speaker: Granny Sanders

utterance: They a'n't nobody come in here lately 'ceppin' the master.
speaker: Granny Sanders

utterance: But I 'low he's allers bore a tip-top character.
speaker: Granny Sanders

utterance: But I think these oversmart young men'll bear looking arter, I do.
speaker: Granny Sanders

utterance: Shouldn't wonder ef our master was overly fond of gals.
speaker: Granny Sanders

utterance: Had plenty of sweethearts afore he walked home with Hanner Thomson t'other night, I'll bet.
speaker: Granny Sanders

utterance: And I think as how that a feller what trifles with gals' hearts and then runs off ten miles, maybe a'n't no better'n he had orter be. I says, says I.
speaker: Granny Sanders

utterance: I allers think, maybe, that some folks has found it best to leave home and go away. You can't never tell. But when people is a-bein' robbed it's well to lookout. Hey?
speaker: Granny Sanders

utterance: I think so.
speaker: Dr. Small

utterance: It's very good for the health to dig in the de ments. I was quite emaciated last year at the East, and the doctor told me to dig in the elements. I got me a florial hoe and dug, and it's been most excellent for me.
speaker: Miss Martha Hawkins

utterance: It's very common for school-master to dig in the elements at the East.
speaker: Miss Martha Hawkins

utterance: When I was to Bosting
speaker: Miss Martha Hawkins

utterance: You here, Miss Hawkins?
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: Bless you, yes, That blessed gyirl that blessed gyirl's the kindest creetur you ever saw-comes here every day, most, to cheer a body up witn somethin' or nuther.
speaker: the old lady

utterance: she came be cause Rocky Hollow looked so much like a place she used to know at the East. Mr. and Mrs. Pear. son were the kindest people. They reminded her of people she knew at the East. When she was to Bosting
speaker: Miss Martha Hawkins

utterance: Pshaw! that talk about kyind. ness is 9 all humbug. I wonder so smart a woman as you don't know better. You come nearder to bein' kyind than anybody I know; but, laws a me! we're all selfish akordin' to my tell.
speaker: Mr. Pearson

utterance: You wasn't selfish when you set up with my father most every night for two weeks.
speaker: Shocky

utterance: Yes, I was, too!
speaker: Mr. Pearson

utterance: Your father was a miserable Britisher. I'd fit red-coats, in the war of eighteentwelve, and lost my leg by one of 'em stickin' his dog-on'd bagonet right through it, that night at Lundy's Lane; but my messmate killed him though, which is a satisfaction to think on. And I didn't like your father 'cause he was a Britisher. But ef he'd a died right here in this free country, 'thout nobody to give him a drink of water, blamed ef I wouldn't a been ashamed to set on the platform at a Fourth of July barbecue, and to hold up my wooden leg fer to make the boys cheer! That was the selfishest thing I ever done. We're all selfish akordin' to my tell.
speaker: Mr. Pearson

utterance: You wasn't selfish when you took me that night, you know.
speaker: Shocky

utterance: Yes, I war, too, you little sass-box! What did I take you fer? Hey? Bekase I didn't like Pete 131 Jones nor Bill Jones. They're thieves, dog-on 'em!
speaker: Mr. Pearson

utterance: Please, Mr. Pearson, be careful. You'll get into trouble, you know, by talking that way.
speaker: Miss Martha Hawkins

utterance: You're just like a man that I knew at the East.
speaker: Miss Martha Hawkins

utterance: Why, do you think an old soldier like me, hob. bling on a wooden leg, is afraid of them thieves? Didn't I face the Britishers? Didn't I come home late last Wednesday night? I rather guess I must a took a little too much at Welch's grocery, and laid down in the middle of the street to rest. The boys thought 'twas funny to crate' me. I woke up kind o' cold, 'bout one in the mornin.' 'Bout
speaker: Mr. Pearson

utterance: two o'clock I come up Means's hill, and didn't I see Pete Jones, and them others that robbed the Dutchman, and somebody, I dunno who, a-crossin' the blue-grass paster towards Jones's?'
speaker: Mr. Pearson

utterance: Don't shake your finger at me, old woman. Tongue is all I've got to fight with now; but I'll fight them thieves tell the sea goes dry, I will. Shocky, gim me a splint.
speaker: Mr. Pearson

utterance: But you wasn't selfish when you tuck me
speaker: Shocky

utterance: Yes, I was, you little tow-headed fool! I didn't take you kase I was good, not a bit of it. I hated Bill Jones what keeps the poor-house, and I knowed him and Pete would get you bound to some of their click, and I didn't want no more thieves raised; so when your mother hobbled, with you a-leadin' her, poor blind thing! all the way over here on that winter night, and said, 'Mr. Pearson, you're all the friend I've got, and I want you to save my boy,' why, you see I was selfish as ever I could be in takin' of you. Your mother's cryin' sot me a-cryin' too. We're all selfish in everything, akordin' to my tell. Blamed ef we ha'n't, Miss Hawkins, only sometimes I'd think you was real benev'lent ef I didn't know we war all selfish.
speaker: Mr. Pearson

utterance: THEY'S preachin' down to Bethel Meetin'-house to-day, I rather guess as how the old man Bosaw will give pertickeler fits to our folks to day.
speaker: Squire Hawkins

utterance: We don't go to church so at the East, The mud isn't so deep at the East. When I was to Bosting
speaker: Miss Martha Hawkins

utterance: seen it so at the East.
speaker: Miss Martha Hawkins

utterance: That horse switches his tail just as they do at the East. When I was to Bosting I saw horses switch their tails just that way.
speaker: Miss Martha Hawkins

utterance: Meetin's took up.
speaker: Pete Jones

utterance: the plamed oid wooden leg was in it anyhow. He'd been seen goin' home at two in the mornin'. And he could name somebody else ef he choosed. But it was best to clean out one at a time.
speaker: Pete Jones

utterance: You see, my respective hearers, you see as how as my tex' says that the ox knoweth his owner and the ass his master's crib. A-h-h! Now, my respective hearers, they're a mighty sight of resemblance atwext men and oxen
speaker: Rev. Mr. Bosaw

utterance: bekase, you see, men is mighty like oxen. Fer they's a tremengious defference atwixt defferent oxen, jest as thar is atwext defferent men; fer the ox knoweth his owner, and the ass ah his master's crib. Now, my respective hearers
speaker: Rev. Mr. Bosaw

utterance: you all know that your humble speaker. ah has got jest the best yoke of steers in this township. They a'n't no sech steers as them air two of mine in this whole keden. try. Them crack oxen over at Clifty ha'n't a patchin' to mine. Fer the ox knoweth his own. er, and the ass ah his master's crib.
speaker: Rev. Mr. Bosaw

utterance: Now, my respective hearers, they's a right smart sight of defference atwext them air two oxen, jest like they is atwext defferent men. Fer ah
speaker: Rev. Mr. Bosaw

utterance: fer ah, you see ah, when I go out ah in the mornin' ah to yoke ah up ah them air steers ah, and I says ah, Wo, Berry ah! Wo, Berry ah! Wo, BERRY-AH', why Berry ah jest stands stock still ah and don't hardly breathe ah while I put on the yoke.
speaker: Rev. Mr. Bosaw

utterance: "He did attack your people, Squire."
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: "Oh, yes. Didn't you see the Sarpent inspirin' him?"
speaker: Squire Hawkins

utterance: "We'll tend to his case & Christmas."
speaker: Mr. Pete Jones

utterance: "How do you 'low he'll get in?"
speaker: Hank Banta

utterance: "How do I 'low? I don't 'low nothin' about it. You might as well ax me where I 'low the nex' shootin' star is a-goin' to drap. Mr. Hartsook's mighty onsartin. But he'll git in, though, and tan your hide fer you, you see ef he don't. Ef he don't blow up the school-house with gunpowder!"
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: "I don't believe he'll come. It's past school-time."
speaker: Hank Banta

utterance: "Yes, he will come, too. And he 'lows to come in here mighty quick. I don't know how. But he'll be a-standin' at that air desk when it's nine o'clock. I'll bet a thousand dollars on that. Ef he don't take it into his head to blow us ap!"
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: "There's the master,"
speaker: Betsey Short

utterance: "Ho! ho! he thinks he'll smoke us out. I guess he'll find us ready."
speaker: Hank Banta

utterance: "I tell you he'll come in. He didn't go to Clifty fer nothin'," said Bud, who sat still on one of the benches which leaned against the door. "I don't know how, but they's lots of ways of killing a cat besides chokin' her with butter. He'll come inef he don't blow us all sky-high!"
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: "Let's open her,"
speaker: Hank Banta

utterance: "Hank, you're a coward. I've got a mind to kick you. You got me into this blamed mess, and now you want to craw fish. You jest tech one of these 'ere fastenin's, and I'll lay you out flat of your back afore you can say Jack Robinson."
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: "That air won't win,"
speaker: Mr. Pete Jones

utterance: "Gunpowder!"
speaker: Mr. Pete Jones

utterance: "It is just nine o'clock, and I'm glad to see you all here promptly. I should have given you a holiday if you had asked me like gentlemen yesterday. On the whole, I think I shall give you a holiday, anyhow. The school is dismissed."
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: "Why, Shocky, haven't you gone yet?"
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: "No-sir-I was waitin' to see if you warn't a-goin', too-I"
speaker: Shocky

utterance: "Well?"
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: "I thought it would make me feel as if God warn't quite so fur away to talk to you. It did the other day."
speaker: Shocky

utterance: "P'r'aps God's forgot you, too,"
speaker: Shocky

utterance: "Better get away from Flat Creek. You see God forgets everybody down here. 'Cause 'most everybody forgets God, 'cept Mr. Bosaw, and I 'low God don't no ways keer tc be remembered by sich as him. Leastways I wouldn't if I was God, you know. I wonder what becomes of folks when God forgets 'em?"
speaker: Shocky

utterance: "Shocky!"
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: "Shocky, you mustn't think God has forgotten you. God brings things out right at last."
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: "Bud, I'd like to see you."
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: "I don't want the rest of you,"
speaker: Ralph Hartsook
addressee: Hank Banta and one or two others

utterance: "Thought maybe you'd want somebody to see far play,"
speaker: Hank Banta

utterance: "If I did, you would be the last one I should ask. There's no unfair play in Bud, and there is in you."
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: "Now, looky here, Mr. Ralph Hartsook, You don't come no gum games over me with your saft sodder and all that. I've made up my mind. You've got to promise to leave these 'ere diggins, or I've got to thrash you."
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: "You'll have to thrash me, then,"
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: "But you'll tell me what it's all about, won't you?"
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: "You know well enough. Folks says you know more 'bout the robbery at the Dutchman's than you orter. But I don't believe them. Fer them as says it is liars and thieves theirselves. 'Ta'n't fer none of that. And I shan't tell you what it is fer. So now, if you won't travel, why, take off your coat and git ready fer a thrashing."
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: "You a'n't a-goin to fight me?"
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: "Not unless you make me."
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: "Why I could chaw you all up."
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: "I know that."
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: "Well, you're the grittiest feller I ever did see, and ef you'd jest kep off of my ground I wouldn't a touched you. But I a'n't a-goin' to be cut out by no feller a livin' 'thout thrashin' him in an inch of his life. You see I wanted to git out of this Flat Crick way. We're a low-lived set here in Flat Crick. And I says to myself, I'll try to be somethin' more nor Pete Jones, and dad, and these other triflin', good-fer-nothin' ones 'bout here. And when you come I says, There's one as'll help me. And what do you do with yor book-larnin' and town manners but start right out to git away the gal that I'd picked out, when I'd picked her out kase I thought, not bein' Flat Crick born herself, she might help a feller to do better! Now I won't let nobody cut me out without givin' 'em the best thrashin' it's in these 'ere arms to give."
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: "But I haven't tried to cut you out."
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: "You can't fool me."
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: "Bud, listen to me, and then thrash me if you will. I went with that girl once. When I found you had some claims, I gave her up. Not because I was afraid of you, for I would rather have taken the worst thrashing you can give me than give her up. But I haven't spoken to her since the night of the irst spelling-school."
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: "You lie!"
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: "You was a-waitin' on her last Sunday right afore my eyes, and a-tryin' to ketch my attention too. So when you're ready say so."
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: "Bud, there is some misunderstanding. I tell you that I did not speak to Hannah last Sunday, and you know I didn't."
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: "Hanner!"
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: "Why, plague take it, who said Han ner?"
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: "Mirandy said you were courting Hannah,"
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: "Mirandy! Thunder! You believed Mirandy! Well! Now, looky here, Mr. Hartsook, ef you was to say that my sister lied, I'd lick you till yer hide wouldn't hold shucks. But I say, a-twix you and me and the gate-post, don't you never believe nothing that Mirandy Means says. Her and marm has set theirselves like fools to git you. Hanner! Well, she's a mighty nice gal, but you're welcome to her. I never tuck no shine that air way. But I was out of school last Thursday and Friday a-shucking corn to take to mill a-Satur. day. And when I come past the Squire's and seed you talking to a gal as is a gal, you know"-here Bud hesitated and looked foolish-" I felt hoppin' mad."
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: "I wanted to say something, but you know it's hard to say it. I ha'n't no book-larnin to speak of, and some things is hard to say when a man ha'n't got book-words to say 'em with. And they's some things a man can't hardly ever say any how to anybody."
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: "You gin up Hanner kase you thought she be longed to me. That's more'n I'd a done by a long shot. Now, arter I left here jest now, I says to myself, a man what can gin up his gal on account of sech a feeling fer the rights of a Flat Cricker like me, why, dog-on it, says I, sech a man is the man 157 as can help me do better. I don't know whether you're a Hardshell or a Saftshell, or a Methodist, or a Campbellite, or a New Light, or a United Brother, or a Millerite, or what-not. But I says, the man what can do the clean thing by a ugly fel ler like me, and stick to it, when I was jest ready to eat him up, is a kind of a man to tie to."
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: "You see, I wanted to git out of this low-lived, Flat Crick way of livin' We're a hard set down here, Mr. Hartsook. And I'm gittin' to be one of the hardest of 'em. But I never could git no good out of Bosaw with his whisky and meanness. And I went to the Mount Tabor church con. cert. I heard a man discussin' baptism, and regen eration, and so on. That didn't seem no cure for me. I went to a revival over at Clifty. Well, 'twarn't no use. First night they was a man that spoke about Jesus Christ in sech a way that I wanted to foller him everywhere. But I didn't feel fit. Next 159 night I come back with my mind made up that I'd try Jesus Christ, and see ef he'd have me. But laws! they was a big man that night that preached hell. Not that I don't believe they's a hell. They's plenty not a thousand miles away as deserves it, and I don't know as I'm too good for it myself. But he pitched it at us, and stuck it in our faces in sech a way that I got mad. And I says, Well, ef God sends me to hell he can't make me holler 'nough mohow. You see my dander was up. And when my dander's up, I wouldn't gin up fer the devil his self. The preacher was so insultin' with his way of doin' it. He seemed to be kind of glad that we was to be damned, and he preached somethin' like some folks swears. It didn't sound a bit like the Christ the little man preached about the night afore. So what does me and a lot of fellers do but slip out and cut off the big preacher's stirrups, and hang 'em on to the rider of the fence, and then set his hoss loose! And from that day, sometimes I did, and sometimes I didn't, want to be better. And to-day it seemed to me that you must know some thin' as would help me."
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: "Do you think that Jesus Christ would-would-well, do you think he'd help a poor, unlarnt Flat Cricker like me?"
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: "I think he was a sort of a Flat Creeker himself,"
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: "You don't say?"
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: "Why, you see the town he lived in was a rough place. It was called Nazareth, which meant' Bushtown."
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: "You don't say?"
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: "And he was called a Nazarene, which was about the same as 'backwoodsman.'"
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: "Can any good thing come out of Nazareth?'"
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: "Jus' what Clifty folks says about Flat Crick,"
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: "Do you think I could begin without being bap tized?"
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: "Why not? Let's begin now to do the best we can, by his help."
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: "You niean, then, that I'm to begin now to put in my best licks for Jesus Christ, and that he'll help me?"
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: "Do you think he'd help a feller? Seems to me it would be number one to have God help you. Not to help you fight other folks, but to help you when it comes to fighting the devil inside. But you see I don't belong to no church "
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: "Well, let's you and me have one right off. Two people that help one another to serve God make a church."
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: "Miss Hawkins-"
speaker: Shocky

utterance: "Miss Hawkins has just been over to say that a crowd is going to tar and feather Mr. Pearson tonight. And here Shocky wept again. And he won't run, but he's took up the old flintlock, and says he'll die in his tracks."
speaker: Shocky

utterance: "Mr. Hartsook, you'd better go straight home to the Squire's. Bekase ef this lightnin' strikes a second time it'll strike awful closte to you. You hadn't better be seen with us. Which way did you come. Shocky?"
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: "Why, I tried to come down the holler, but I met Jones right by the big road, and he sweared at me and said he'd kill me ef I didn't go back and stay. And so I went back to the house and then slipped out through the graveyard. You see I was 165 bound to come ef I got skinned. For Mr. Pearson's stuck to me and I mean to stick to him, you see."
speaker: Shocky

utterance: "Now, Shocky, do you run ahead and tell the ole man that I want to see him right off down by the Spring-in-rock. I'll keep closte behind you, and ef anybody offers to trouble you, do you let off a yell and I'll be thar in no time."
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: "You good-for-nothing scoundrel, you're a coward and a thief to be a-beatin' a little creetur like him!" and with that Bud walked up on Jones, who prudently changed position in such a way as to get the upper side of the hill.
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: "Well, I'll gin you the upper side, but come on, ef you a'n't afeared to fight somebody besides a poor little sickly baby or a crippled soldier. Come on!"
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: "I'm afraid you're going to have trouble with your arm, Bud,"
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: "Never mind; I put in my best licks fer Him, that air time, Mr. Hartsook."
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: "No, I won't leave. You see I jest won't. What would Gin'ral Winfield Scott say ef he knew that one of them as fit at Lundy's Lane backed out, retreated, run fer fear of a passel of thieves? No, sir; me and the old flintlock will live and die together. I'll put a thunderin' charge of buckshot into the first one of them scoundrels as comes up the holler. It'll be another Lundy's Lane. And you, Mr. Hartsook, may send Scott word that ole Pearson, as fit at Lundy's Lane 169 under him, died a-fightin' thieves on Rocky Branch, in Hoopole Kyounty, State of Injea ny."
speaker: Mr. Pearson

utterance: "Halt! Who goes there?"
speaker: Mr. Pearson

utterance: "It's me, Mr. Pearson. Don't shoot me, please."
speaker: Hannah Thomson

utterance: Well, the enemy is not coming yet. Let us hold a council of war.
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: Now, I suppose, that General Winfield Scott always looked into things a little before he went into a fight. Didn't he?
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: To be sure.
speaker: Old John Pearson

utterance: Well. What is the condition of the enemy? I suppose the whole neighborhood's against us.
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: To be sure.
speaker: Old John Pearson

utterance: Next, I suppose General Winfield Scott would always inquire into the condition of his own troops. Now let us see. Captain Pearson has Bud, who is the right wing, badly crippled by hav ing his arm broken in the first battle.
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: To be sure.
speaker: Old John Pearson

utterance: And I am the left wing, pretty good at giving advice, but very slender in a fight.
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: To be sure.
speaker: Old John Pearson

utterance: And Shocky and Miss Martha and Hannah good aids, but nothing in a battle.
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: To be sure.
speaker: Old John Pearson

utterance: Well, this old musket has been loaded
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: This ten year.
speaker: Mrs. Pearson

utterance: And the lock is so rusty that you could not cock it when you wanted to take aim at Hannah.
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: To be sure.
speaker: Old John Pearson

utterance: And there isn't another round of ammunition in the house.
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: Now let us look at the incumbrances. Here's the old lady and Shocky. If you fight, the enemy will be pleased. It will give them a chance to kill you. And then the old lady will die and they will do with Shocky as they please.
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: To be sure.
speaker: Old John Pearson

utterance: Now, General Winfield Scott, under such circumstances, would retreat in good order. Then, when he could muster his forces rightly, he would drive the enemy from his ground.
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: To be sure. What ort I to do?
speaker: Old John Pearson

utterance: Have you any friends?
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: Well, yes; ther's my brother over in Jackson Kyounty. I mout go there.
speaker: Old John Pearson

utterance: Well, do you just go down to Spring. in-rock and stay there. Them folks won't be here tell midnight. I'll come fer you at nine with my roan colt, and I'll set you down over on the big road on Buckeye Run. Then you can git on the mail wagon that passes there about five o'clock in the mornin', and go over to Jackson County and keep shady till we want you to face the enemy and to swear agin some folks. And then we'll send fer you.
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: To be sure. I reckon General Winfield Scott wouldn't disapprove of such a maneuver as that thar.
speaker: Old John Pearson

utterance: Well, good-by, ole woman, good-by. I didn't never think I'd desart you, and ef the old flintlock hadn't a been rusty. I'd a staid and died right here by the ole cabin. But I reckon 'ta'n't best to be brash.
speaker: Old John Pearson

utterance: Good-by. Ef I'm wanted jest send me word, and I'll make a forrard movement any time. I don't like this 'ere thing of running off in the night-time. But I reckon General Winfield Scott would a ordered a retreat ef he'd a been in 175 my shoes. I'm lots obleeged to you. Akordin' to my tell, we're all of us selfish ir. everything; but I'll be dog-on'd ef I don't believe you and one or two more is exceptions.
speaker: Old John Pearson

utterance: She'd allers said so. Ef she'd a been consulted he wouldn't a been hired. He warn't fit company fer nobody.
speaker: Mrs. Old Jack Means

utterance: They're coming, they're coming. Pete Jones is a-going to bind me out for a hundred years. I wish Hanner would hold me so's he couldn't. God's forgot all about us here in Flat Creek, and there's nobody to help it.
speaker: Shocky

utterance: You see, Mr. Hartsook, I ha'n't forgot what we said about puttin' in our best licks for Jesus Christ. I've been a trying to read some about him while I set here. And I read where he said something about doing fer the least of his brethren being all the same like as if it was done fer Jesus Christ hisscif. Now there's Shocky. I reckon, p'r'aps, ef anybody is a little brother of Jesus Christ, it is that Shocky. Pete Jones and his brother Bill is detarmined to have him back there to-morry. Bekase, you see, Pete's one of the County Commissioners, 179 and to-morry's the day that they bind out. He wants to bind out that boy jes' to spite ole Pearson and you and me. You see, the ole woman's been helped by the neighbors, and he'll claim Shocky to be a pauper, and they a'n't no human soul here at dares to do a thing contrary to Pete. Couldn't yo git him over to Lewisburg? I'll lend you my roan colt.
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: Hannah-
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: You don't believe all these lies that are told about me.
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: I don't believe anything, Mr. Hartsook; that is, I don't want to believe anything against you. And I wouldn't mind anything they say if it wasn't for two things -here she stammered and looked down.
speaker: Hannah Thomson

utterance: If it wasn't for what?
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: I saw you cross that blue-grass pasture the night-the night that you walked home with me.
speaker: Hannah Thomson

utterance: I did cross the pasture, but-
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: Tell me what else you have against me.
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: I haven't anything against you. Only I am poor and friendless, and you oughtn't to make my life any heavier. They say that you have paid attention to a great many girls. I don't know why you should want to trifle with me.
speaker: Hannah Thomson

utterance: If any man says that I ever trifled with any woman, he lies. I have never loved but one, and you know who that is. And God knows.
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: I don't know what to say, Mr. Hartsook. If I was alone, it wouldn't matter. But I've got my blind mother and my poor Shocky to look after. And I don't want to make mistakes. And the world is so full of lies I don't know what to believe. Somehow I can't help believing what you say. You seem to speak so true. But
speaker: Hannah Thomson

utterance: But what?
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: But you know how I saw you just as kind to Martha Hawkins on Sunday as-as
speaker: Hannah Thomson

utterance: Han-ner!
speaker: Mrs. Old Jack Means

utterance: You see, Mr. Hartsook, I wish I was well myself. It's hard to set still. But it's a-doing me a heap of good. I'm like a boy at school. And I'm a-findin' out that doing one's best licks fer others ain't all they is of it, though it's a good part. I feel like as if I must git Him, you know, to do lots for me. They's always some sums too hard fer a feller, and he has to ax the master to do 'em, you know. But see, the roan's a-stomping round. He wants to be off. Do you know I think that hoss knows something's up? I think he puts in his best licks fer me a good deal better than I do fer Him.
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: Put in your best licks, old fellow.
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: He'll put in his best licks,
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: O Mr. Hartsook! is that you? What a storm! This is jest the way it snows at the East. Shocky's all ready. He didn't know a thing about it tell I waked him this morning. Ever since that he's been saying that God hasn't forgot, after all. It's made me cry more'n once.
speaker: Miss Martha Hawkins

utterance: O Miss Hawkins! God ha'n't forgot me, after all. Tell Hanner that He ha'n't forgot. I'm going to ask him to git her away from Means's and mother out of the poor-house. I'll ask him just as soon as I get to Lewisburg.
speaker: Shocky

utterance: You see, Mr. Hartsook, I thought God had forgot. But he ha'n't.
speaker: Shocky

utterance: See, Mr. Hartsook, how big it is, and how little and ugly the windows is! And the boards is peeling off all over it, and the hogs is right in the front yard. It don't look just like a house. It looks dreadful. What is it?
speaker: Shocky

utterance: Is that the poor-house? Is my mother in that place? We't you take me in there, so as I can just kiss her once? 'Cause she can't see much, you know. And one kiss from me will make her feel so good. And I'll tell her that God ha'n't forgot.
speaker: Shocky

utterance: Why, Ralph Hartsook, where did you drop down from-and what have you got?
speaker: Miss Nancy Sawyer

utterance: I came from Flat Creek this morning, and I 1 13 brought you a little angel who has got out of heaven, and needs some of your motherly care.
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: Who are you?
speaker: Miss Nancy Sawyer

utterance: I'm Shocky, a little boy as God forgot, and then thought of again.
speaker: Shocky

utterance: How did you get here so early, Ralph ?
speaker: Aunt Matilda

utterance: By early rising.
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: Yes, Sister Sawyer has no family cares, she said by way of smoothing her slightly ruffled com placency, she has no family cares, and she can do those things. Sometimes I think she lets people impose on her and keep her away from the means of grace, and I spoke to our new preacher about it the last time he was here, and asked him to speak to Sister Sawyer about staying away from the ordinances to wait on everybody, but he is a queer man, and he only said that he supposed Sister Sawyer neglected the inferior ordinances that she might attend to higher ones. But I don't see any sense in a minister of the gospel calling prayer. meeting a lower ordinance than feeding catnip-tea to Mrs. Brown's last baby. But hasn't this little boy-Shocking, or what do you call him?-got any mother?
speaker: Aunt Matilda

utterance: Yes, and that was just what I was going to say.
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: Bless my stars! fetch a pauper here? What crazy notions you have got! Fetch her here out of the poor-house? Why, she wouldn't be fit to sleep in my
speaker: Aunt Matilda

utterance: Aunt Matilda, do you think Dorcas was afraid of sore eyes?
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: It seems to me, Ralph, that you have picked up some very low associates. And you go around at over here by daylight, night, I am told. You get and I hear that you have made common cause with a lame soldier who acts as a spy for thieves, and that your running about of night is likely to get you into trouble.
speaker: Aunt Matilda

utterance: I suppose that you've been listening to some of Henry Small's lies.
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: Why, Ralph, how you talk! The worst sign of all is that you abuse such a young man as Dr. Small, the most exemplary Christian young man in the county. And he is a great friend of yours, for when he was here last week he did not say a word against you, but looked so sorry when your being in trouble was mentioned. Didn't he, Mr. White?
speaker: Aunt Matilda

utterance: Where is Walter?
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: Oh! Walter's doing well. He went down to Clifty three weeks ago to study medicine with Henry Small. He seems so fond of the doctor, and the doctor is such an excellent man, you know, and I have strong hopes that Wallie will be led to see the error of hi
speaker: Aunt Matilda

utterance: I declare that boy has stepped right on the threshold of the backdoor.
speaker: Mrs. Matilda White

utterance: Ralph, I want you to get a buggy or a sleigh, and go right over to the poor-house and fetch that boy's mother over here. It'll do me more good than any sermon I ever heard to see that boy in his mother's arms tomorrow. We can keep the old lady over Sunday.
speaker: Miss Nancy Sawyer

utterance: he warn't goin' to have brats a-runnin' over the whole house.
speaker: Mr. Pete Jones

utterance: That air woman used to holler a heap when she was brought in here. But Pap knows how to subjue 'em. He slapped her in the mouth every time she hollered. She don't make no furss now, but jist sets down that way all day, and keeps a-whisperin'.
speaker: weak-eyed girl

utterance: Don't you think they ought to let me go home?
speaker: Phil

utterance: Don't you think I might go home now?
speaker: Phil

utterance: I am General Andrew Jackson. People don't believe it, but I am. I had my head shot off at Bueny Visty, and the new one that growed on isn't nigh so good as the old one; it's tater on one side.' That's why they take advantage Of me to shut me up. But I know some things. My head is tater on one side, but it's all right on t'other. And when I know a thing in the left side of my head, I know it. Lean down here. Let me tell you something out of the left side. Not out of the tater side, mind ye. I wouldn't a told you if he hadn't locked me up fer nothing. Bill Jones is a thief! He sells the bodies of the dead paupers, and then sells the empty coffins back to the county agin. But that a'n't all
speaker: General Andrew Jackson

utterance: That a'n't all. I'll tell the rest another time. And that a'n't out of the tater side, you can depend on that. That's out of the left side. Sound as a nut on that side!
speaker: General Andrew Jackson

utterance: Don't go in there. Ole Mowley's in there, and she'll cuss you.
speaker: weak-eyed girl

utterance: Oh! well, if that's all, her curses won't hurt,
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: Is this Mrs. Thomson?
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: That is my name, sir.
speaker: Hannah Thomson

utterance: I saw your daughter yesterday.
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: Did you see my boy?
speaker: Hannah Thomson

utterance: Good-by! good-by!
speaker: Phil

utterance: God ha'n't forgot us, mother; God ha'n't forgot us.
speaker: Shocky

utterance: Is your arm improving?
speaker: Miss Martha Hawkins

utterance: Yes, I think it is.
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: Have you heard from Mr. Pearson?
speaker: Miss Martha Hawkins

utterance: No, I ha'n't.
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: Beautiful sunshine, isn't it?
speaker: Miss Martha Hawkins

utterance: Yes, 'tis.
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: This snow looks like the snow we have at the East. It snowed that way the time I was to Bosting.
speaker: Miss Martha Hawkins

utterance: Did it?
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: I suppose Mr. Hartsook rode your horse to Lewisburg?
speaker: Miss Martha Hawkins

utterance: Yes, he did;
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: You were very kind.
speaker: Miss Martha Hawkins

utterance: You see, Miss Hawkins, I thought as how I'd come over here to-day, and
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: I'm glad to see you, Mr. Means.
speaker: Miss Martha Hawkins

utterance: and I thought I'd tell you -Martha was sure it was coming now, for Bud was in dead earnest- and I thought I'd just like to tell you, ef I only know'd jest how to tell it right I thought as how you might like to know-or ruther I wanted to tell you-that-the-that I-that we-all of us-think-that-I-that we are going to have a spellin'-school a Chewsday night.
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: I'm real glad to hear it. We used to have spelling schools at the East.
speaker: Miss Martha Hawkins

utterance: Kin I see you safe home?
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: No, I thank you.
speaker: Miss Martha Hawkins

utterance: Might a knowed it. Of .course, a smart gal like Martha a'n't agoin' to take a big, blunderin' fool that can't spell in two sylla bles. What's the use of tryin'? A Flat Cricker i a Flat Cricker. You can't make nothin' else cut of him, no more nor you can make a Chiny hog inte a Berkshire.
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: O Hank! be sure to ook at the Spring-in-rock-I think he's there.
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: Is that you, Mr. Hartsook?
speaker: Squire Hawkins

utterance: Yes, and I want you to arrest me and try me here in Clifty.
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: Dear Ralph:
speaker: Aunt Matilda

utterance: This is what I have always been afraid of. I warned you faithfully the last time I saw you. My 234 235 skirts are clear of your blood. I can not consent for your uncle to appear as your counsel or to go your bail. You know how much it would injure him in the county, and he has no right to suffer for your evil acts. O my dear nephew! for the sake of your poor, dead mother
speaker: Aunt Matilda

utterance: Well, you see, I allers suspected that air young man
speaker: Mrs. Sarah Jane Means

utterance: Well, it's facts I am a-going to tell.
speaker: Mrs. Sarah Jane Means

utterance: It's facts that I mean to tell.
speaker: Mrs. Sarah Jane Means

utterance: Well, fer one thing, what kind of gals did he go with? Hey? Why, with my bound gal, Hanner, a-loafin' along through the blue-grass paster at ten o'clock, and keepin' that gal that's got no protector but me out that a-way, and destroyin' her character by his company, that a'n't fit fer nobody.
speaker: Mrs. Sarah Jane Means

utterance: Did I ever go with your daughter Miranda?
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: No, you didn't.
speaker: Mrs. Sarah Jane Means

utterance: Looky here, Squar,
speaker: Mr. Pearson

utterance: looky here. I jes want to say that I kin tell as much about this case as any. body.
speaker: Mr. Pearson

utterance: Let us hear it, then.
speaker: Bronson

utterance: Young man! you who have followed the counsel of evil companions
speaker: Mr. Soden

utterance: I mean you who have chosen evil pursuits and who can not get free from bad habits and associations that are dragging you down to hell! You are standing on the very crumbling brink of hell tonight. The smell of the brimstone is on your garments; the hot breath of hell is in your face! The devils are waiting for you! Delay and you are damned! You may die before daylight! You may never get out that door! The awful angel of death is just ready to strike you down!
speaker: Mr. Soden

utterance: Tell the truth or go to penitentiary.
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: Please tell the court whether you know anything of the whereabouts of Dr. Smail on the night of the robbery at Peter Schroeder's.
speaker: Bronson

utterance: On the night of the robbery Dr. Small came home before
speaker: Walter Johnson

utterance: I can't, I can't. O God! What shall I do?
speaker: Walter Johnson

utterance: If the court please, this witness is evidently intimidated by that stout young man.
speaker: Bronson

utterance: I have seen him twice interrupt witness's testimony by casting threatening looks at 259 him. I trust the court will have him removed from the court-room.
speaker: Bronson

utterance: The witness will please proceed.
speaker: Bronson

utterance: If the court please
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: I believe I have as much at stake in this trial as any one. That witness is evidently intimidated. But not by Mr. Means. I ask that Dr. Small be removed out of sight of the witness.
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: A most extraordinary request, truly.
speaker: Dr. Small

utterance: It's no more than fair that the witness be relieved of everything that anybody might think affects his veracity in this matter.
speaker: Squire Hawkins

utterance: The witness will now proceed with his testimony.
speaker: Squire Hawkins

utterance: Please proceed.
speaker: Squire Hawkins

utterance: Well, then,
speaker: Walter Johnson

utterance: if I must
speaker: Walter Johnson

utterance: well, then, I hope you won't send me to prison
speaker: Walter Johnson

utterance: but, oh! I don't see how I can!
speaker: Walter Johnson

utterance: "Dr. Small's trying to git out, plague take him, I'd like the court to send and git his trunk afore he has a chance to burn up all the papers that's in it."
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: "Constable, you will arrest Dr. Small, Peter Jones, and William Jones. Send two deputies to bring Small's trunk into court"
speaker: Squire Underwood

utterance: "To be sure"
speaker: Mr. Pearson

utterance: "'Squar, I kin tell you somethin'. I'm Gineral Andrew Jackson. Lost my head at Bueny Visty. This head growed on. It a'n't good fer much. One side's tater. But t'other's sound as a nut. Now, I kind give you information."
speaker: Tom Bifield

utterance: "If the court please, this man is not wholly sane, but we might get valuable information out of him. I suggest that his testimony be taken for what it is worth."
speaker: George H. Bronson

utterance: "No, you don't swar me, Not if I knows myself. You see, when a feller's got one side of his head tater, he's mighty onsartain like. You don't swar me, fer I can't tell what minute the tater side'll begin to talk. I'm talkin' out of the lef' side now, and I'm all right. But you don't swar me. But ef you'll send some of your constables out to the barn at the pore-housc and look under the hay-mow in the north-east corner, you'll find some things maybe as has been a-missin' fer some time. And that a'n't out of the tater side, nuther."
speaker: Tom Bifield

utterance: "To be sure"
speaker: Mr. Pearson

utterance: "Be care ful, Mr. Pearson, or I shall have to punish you for contempt."
speaker: Squire Hawkins

utterance: "Why, Squar, I didn't know 'twas any sin to hev a healthy contemp' fer sech a thief as Jones!"
speaker: Mr. Pearson

utterance:
"If the court please, I have tried to do my duty in this case. It was my duty to pros ecute Mr. Hartsook, however much I might feel assured that he was innocent, and that he would be able to prove his innocence. I now enter a nolle in his case and that of John Pearson, and I ask that this court adjourn until to-morrow, in order to give me time to examine the evidence in the case of the other parties under arrest. I am proud to think that my efforts have been the means of sifting the matter to the bottom, of freeing Mr.
Hartsook from suspicion, and of detecting the real criminals."
speaker: George H. Bronson

utterance: "Ugh!"
speaker: Mr. Pearson

utterance: "The court, congratulates Mr. Hartsook on his triumphant acquittal. He is discharged from the bar of this court, and from the bar of public sentiment, without a suspi cion of guilt. Constable, discharge Ralph Hartsook and John Pearson."
speaker: Squire Hawkins

utterance: "Jack Means allers wuz a fcoi!"
speaker: Mrs. Old Jack Means

utterance: "This court has one other duty to perform before adjourning for the day. Recall Hannah Thomson."
speaker: Squire Underwood

utterance: "I jist started her on ahead to git supper and milk the cows. A'n't a-goin' to have her loafin' here all day."
speaker: Mrs. Old Jack Means

utterance: "Constable, recall her. This court can not ad journ until she returns!"
speaker: Squire Underwood

utterance: "Hannah Thomson - Hannah Thomson, this court wishes to ask you one or two questions."
speaker: Squire Underwood

utterance: "Yes, sir,"
speaker: Hannah Thomson

utterance: "How old did you say you were?"
speaker: Squire Underwood

utterance: "Eighteen, sir, last October."
speaker: Hannah Thomson

utterance: "Can you prove your age?"
speaker: Squire Underwood

utterance: "Yes, sir--by my mother."
speaker: Hannah Thomson

utterance: "For how long are you bound to Mr. Means?
speaker: Squire Underwood

utterance: "Till I'm twenty-one."
speaker: Hannah Thomson

utterance: "This court feels in duty bound to inform you that, according to the laws of Indiana, a woman is of age at eighteen, and as no indenture could be made binding after you had reached your majority, you are the victim of a deception. You are free, and if it can be proven that you have been defrauded by a willful deception, a suit for damages will lie."
speaker: Squire Underwood

utterance: "Ugh! You're a purty court, a'n't you, Dr. Underwood?"
speaker: Mrs. Old Jack Means

utterance: "Be careful, Mrs. Means, or I shall have to fine you for contempt of court."
speaker: Squire Underwood

utterance: "You mis'able, ongrateful critter you, go 'long. I'm glad to be shed of you!"
speaker: Mrs. Old Jack Means

utterance: "Where are you going? Can I--"
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: "No, no!"
speaker: Hannah Thomson

utterance: "O mother! I'm free! I'm free!"
speaker: Hannah Thomson

utterance: "I knowed God wouldn't forget you, Hanner!"
speaker: Shocky

utterance:
"Bud, my dear friend, it looks a little hard to ask you to take a new wife to the poor. house. But I don't know anywhere where you can do so much good for Christ as by taking charge of that place, and I can get the appointment for you.

The new commissioners want just such a man."
speaker: Ralph Hartsook

utterance: "What d'ye say, Marthy?"
speaker: Bud Means

utterance: "Why, somebody ought to do for the poor, and I should like to do it"
speaker: Miss Martha Hawkins
